dietary_restrictions: Low sodium (1.5g/day), Fluid restriction (1.5L/day), Low Phosphorus
follow_up: Nephrology clinic in 10 days, Primary Care in 4 weeks
warning_signs: Swelling, shortness of breath, decreased urine output, sudden weight gain
discharge_instructions: Monitor blood pressure and weight daily. Use pill organizer for new medications.

dietary_restrictions: Low sodium (2g/day), Fluid restriction (2L/day)
follow_up: Cardiology clinic in 7 days, Home Health Nurse visit next day
warning_signs: Sudden weight gain (3+ lbs in 2 days), increased leg swelling, difficulty breathing while lying down
discharge_instructions: Weigh yourself every morning before breakfast. Keep a log of your weight and fluid intake.

medications: Albuterol HFA Inhaler as needed for shortness of breath
dietary_restrictions: None (encourage high-protein diet)
follow_up: Primary Care Physician in 1 week for chest X-ray follow-up
warning_signs: Fever above 100.4°F, shaking chills, worsening cough, chest pain, confusion
discharge_instructions: Complete the full course of antibiotics. Practice deep breathing and coughing exercises every 2 hours while awake.

dietary_restrictions: Diabetic Diet (Limit simple sugars, consistent carbohydrate intake)
follow_up: Endocrinology clinic in 2 weeks, Diabetes Education class next week
warning_signs: Excessive thirst/urination, confusion, fruity breath odor, signs of low blood sugar (shakiness, sweating)
discharge_instructions: Monitor blood glucose four times daily (before meals and at bedtime). Know the signs of hypoglycemia and carry a source of sugar.

medications: Oxycodone 5mg every 4-6 hours as needed for pain
Rivaroxaban 10mg daily for DVT prophylaxis (30 days)
dietary_restrictions: None (Ensure high-fiber to prevent constipation from pain medication)
follow_up: Orthopedic Surgeon in 2 weeks, Outpatient Physical Therapy three times a week
warning_signs: Fever above 100.4°F, severe pain unrelieved by medication, redness/swelling/pus at incision site, calf pain/swelling
discharge_instructions: Follow hip precautions (no bending past 90 degrees, no crossing legs). Keep incision clean and dry.

medications: Phenazopyridine 200mg three times daily as needed for pain
dietary_restrictions: Encourage fluid intake (2-3L/day)
follow_up: Primary Care for urine culture recheck in 7-10 days
warning_signs: Fever/chills, flank pain, severe nausea/vomiting, blood in urine
discharge_instructions: Drink plenty of water and complete the full course of Ciprofloxacin. Urine may turn orange/red from Phenazopyridine.

dietary_restrictions: Dysphagia Diet (Thickened liquids, pureed foods) - per Speech Therapy
follow_up: Rehabilitation facility transfer tomorrow, Neurology clinic in 4 weeks
warning_signs: Sudden weakness/numbness on one side of the body, slurred speech, facial droop, severe headache
discharge_instructions: Continue recommended exercises. Use assistive devices as instructed. Know the signs of a recurrent stroke (BE FAST).

medications: Fluticasone Propionate Inhaler 2 puffs twice daily
dietary_restrictions: None
follow_up: Pulmonology clinic in 2 weeks to review Asthma Action Plan
warning_signs: Worsening shortness of breath, wheezing that does not improve with rescue inhaler, chest tightness
discharge_instructions: Use your rescue inhaler before calling for help. Keep a symptom diary. Avoid known triggers.

medications: Nitroglycerin sublingual 0.4mg as needed for chest pain
dietary_restrictions: Cardiac Diet (Low fat, low cholesterol, low sodium)
follow_up: Cardiac Rehabilitation enrollment within 1 week, Cardiology in 1 week
warning_signs: New or worsening chest pain, pain radiating to arm/jaw/back, dizziness, feeling faint
discharge_instructions: Take Nitroglycerin if chest pain occurs. If pain is unrelieved after 5 minutes and one dose, call 911. Avoid heavy lifting.

dietary_restrictions: Monitor fluid intake. Encourage balanced, low-sodium meals.
follow_up: Obstetrics (OB) follow-up in 3 days, Primary Care in 2 weeks
warning_signs: Severe, persistent headache, vision changes (blurry, spots), upper right abdominal pain, sudden swelling of hands/face
discharge_instructions: Monitor blood pressure twice daily. Report any 'POST-BIRTH' warning signs to your OB immediately.

primary_diagnosis: Exacerbation of Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease (COPD)
dietary_restrictions: Eat small, frequent, high-calorie meals to conserve energy.
follow_up: Pulmonology clinic in 1 week, Smoking Cessation Program enrollment
warning_signs: Increased shortness of breath, change in color/thickness of sputum, use of accessory breathing muscles, confusion
discharge_instructions: Continue home oxygen therapy as prescribed. Use pursed-lip breathing technique daily.

medications: Acetaminophen 500mg every 6 hours as needed for pain
dietary_restrictions: None
follow_up: Primary Care Physician in 7 days to check infection site
warning_signs: Spreading redness/swelling/warmth, fever above 100.4°F, new drainage or pus from site, severe pain
discharge_instructions: Elevate the affected leg above heart level when sitting. Complete all antibiotics. Keep the area clean.

medications: Cyclobenzaprine 5mg at bedtime for muscle spasm
dietary_restrictions: None
follow_up: Pain Management specialist in 10 days, Outpatient Physical Therapy
warning_signs: New or worsening weakness/numbness in legs/feet, loss of bowel or bladder control
discharge_instructions: Do not lift more than 10 lbs. Maintain proper body mechanics (lift with legs, not back). Apply heat/ice as tolerated.

dietary_restrictions: Strict Fluid Restriction (1.2L/day) until follow-up
follow_up: Endocrinology in 5 days for electrolyte panel recheck
warning_signs: Confusion, severe headache, muscle cramps, lethargy, seizures
discharge_instructions: Adhere strictly to the fluid restriction. Avoid excessive intake of plain water. Record daily fluid intake.

primary_diagnosis: Atrial Fibrillation with Rapid Ventricular Response (New Onset)
dietary_restrictions: None (If on Warfarin, a Vitamin K consistent diet would be needed)
follow_up: Cardiology in 1 week, PCP in 4 weeks
warning_signs: Irregular or racing heart beat, dizziness, fainting, shortness of breath, bleeding/bruising easily (from Apixaban)
discharge_instructions: Take Apixaban exactly as prescribed. Avoid contact sports. Check your pulse rate daily.

medications: Ondansetron 4mg every 8 hours as needed for nausea
dietary_restrictions: BRAT diet (Bananas, Rice, Applesauce, Toast) for 24-48 hours, then gradual return to regular diet.
follow_up: Primary Care Physician in 3 days if symptoms persist
warning_signs: Inability to keep fluids down for 12+ hours, severe abdominal pain, high fever, blood in stool or vomit
discharge_instructions: Sip clear fluids and electrolyte solutions (Pedialyte, Gatorade) frequently. Wash hands often.

dietary_restrictions: High-protein, vitamin-rich diet. No alcohol or caffeine.
follow_up: Outpatient Substance Abuse Counseling and AA meeting enrollment
warning_signs: Shaking, hallucinations, seizures, severe anxiety, confusion, craving for alcohol
discharge_instructions: Attend all scheduled therapy sessions. Have a sober support person check in daily.

medications: Ibuprofen 400mg every 6 hours as needed for pain
Docusate Sodium 100mg twice daily for constipation
dietary_restrictions: Low-fat diet for 4-6 weeks (avoid fried and greasy foods).
follow_up: General Surgeon in 1 week
warning_signs: Fever, worsening abdominal pain, persistent nausea/vomiting, yellowing of skin or eyes (jaundice), bile leakage from incision
discharge_instructions: Keep incision sites clean and dry. Avoid heavy lifting (over 15 lbs) for 6 weeks. Increase walking daily.

medications: Tums as needed for breakthrough symptoms
dietary_restrictions: Avoid acidic foods (citrus, tomatoes), mint, chocolate, caffeine, and alcohol.
follow_up: PCP in 4 weeks if symptoms do not improve with medication
warning_signs: Bloody vomit or black stool (sign of bleeding ulcer), difficulty swallowing, severe chest pain
discharge_instructions: Do not lie down for 3 hours after eating. Elevate the head of the bed 6-8 inches.

primary_diagnosis: Septicemia (Sepsis) secondary to central line infection
medications: Acetaminophen 500mg every 6 hours as needed for fever
dietary_restrictions: High-calorie, high-protein diet to aid recovery.
follow_up: Infectious Disease clinic in 7 days, Home Health Nurse daily for IV antibiotics
warning_signs: Fever/chills, confusion, extreme pain, clammy skin, signs of infection at PICC line site (redness, pus, swelling)
discharge_instructions: Keep PICC line dressing clean and dry. Complete the full 6-week course of IV antibiotics. Monitor temperature twice daily.

dietary_restrictions: Maintain consistent salt and fluid intake (for Lithium monitoring). Avoid crash dieting.
follow_up: Outpatient Behavioral Health follow-up in 3 days, Psychiatry in 1 week
warning_signs: Increased grandiose thinking, decreased need for sleep, rapid or pressured speech, thoughts of self-harm
discharge_instructions: Take medications exactly as prescribed. Attend all therapy appointments. Schedule blood work for Lithium level next week.

dietary_restrictions: DASH diet (Dietary Approaches to Stop Hypertension) - low sodium, high potassium, calcium, magnesium.
follow_up: Vascular Neurology clinic in 1 week, Imaging recheck in 3 months
warning_signs: Recurrence of stroke-like symptoms (facial droop, arm weakness, slurred speech), sudden severe headache
discharge_instructions: Monitor blood pressure daily. Maintain blood pressure within target range (<140/90). Begin walking program 3x/week.

dietary_restrictions: Strict low-fat diet. No alcohol. Small, frequent meals.
follow_up: Gastroenterology in 2 weeks, Nutrition counseling next week
warning_signs: Severe abdominal pain radiating to the back, vomiting, fever, jaundice
discharge_instructions: Absolutely no alcohol consumption. Take enzyme supplements with every meal/snack. Follow-up for pain management.

primary_diagnosis: Post-Exploratory Laparotomy for Small Bowel Obstruction (SBO)
medications: Morphine PCA pump removed, transitioning to oral pain meds (Hydrocodone/Acetaminophen 5/325mg every 6 hours as needed)
dietary_restrictions: Advance to soft, bland, low-fiber diet as tolerated. Chew thoroughly. Avoid gas-producing foods.
follow_up: General Surgeon in 7-10 days
warning_signs: Inability to pass gas or stool, abdominal distension, severe nausea/vomiting, fever, drainage from incision
discharge_instructions: Walk for 10-15 minutes 3 times a day. Do not lift anything over 10 lbs for 8 weeks. Keep incision clean and dry.

medications: Ferrous Sulfate 325mg three times daily with Vitamin C
Esomeprazole 40mg daily (while determining cause of blood loss)
dietary_restrictions: Iron-rich foods (lean meats, leafy greens). Avoid taking Ferrous Sulfate with milk or caffeine.
follow_up: Hematology/Oncology in 2 weeks for further work-up, PCP for weekly blood check
warning_signs: Extreme fatigue, paleness, dizziness/fainting, shortness of breath on exertion, chest pain
discharge_instructions: Increase iron and Vitamin C intake. Iron may cause black stools and constipation. Follow up promptly for all blood tests.

dietary_restrictions: None (Focus on balanced anti-inflammatory diet)
follow_up: Rheumatology in 1 week, Ophthalmology in 6 months (for Hydrochloroquine side effects)
warning_signs: New or worsening joint pain/swelling, severe fatigue, rash (especially butterfly rash on face), fever
discharge_instructions: Avoid excessive sun exposure. Monitor for signs of infection due to steroids. Stay well-rested.

primary_diagnosis: Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT) in Left Leg
dietary_restrictions: None
follow_up: Hematology in 1 week, Doppler ultrasound recheck in 3 months
warning_signs: Increased pain/swelling/redness in the leg, sudden shortness of breath, sharp chest pain (signs of Pulmonary Embolism - PE)
discharge_instructions: Wear compression stockings as instructed. Stay active and walk regularly. Take blood thinners exactly as directed.

dietary_restrictions: None (High fiber to counteract opioid-induced constipation)
follow_up: Spine Surgeon in 2 weeks, Pain Clinic in 3 weeks, Home Health PT/OT visits initiated
warning_signs: Fever, chills, severe pain unrelieved by medication, new leg weakness/numbness, drainage from surgical site, loss of bladder control
discharge_instructions: NO bending, lifting, or twisting (BLT precautions). Use a walker/cane for assistance. Keep surgical site clean and dry.

dietary_restrictions: Cardiac Diet (Low saturated fat, low cholesterol)
follow_up: Cardiology in 1 week, Cardiac Rehab within 10 days
warning_signs: Bleeding/swelling/lump at catheter site (groin/wrist), chest pain, fever, signs of stroke/TIA
discharge_instructions: Do not lift heavy objects or strain for 1 week. Keep catheter site clean and dry. Complete dual antiplatelet therapy as prescribed.

dietary_restrictions: None (Anti-inflammatory diet encouraged)
follow_up: Rheumatology in 2 weeks, Laboratory tests in 1 week (for Methotrexate monitoring)
warning_signs: Fever, signs of infection (due to immunosuppressants), new joint deformities, vision changes (from Hydroxychloroquine)
discharge_instructions: Avoid large crowds while on Prednisone. Report any signs of infection immediately. Take Folic Acid to prevent side effects of Methotrexate.
